citation.article-title: Clostridium halophilium sp. nov. and Clostridium litorale sp. nov., an obligate halophilic and a marine species degrading betaine in the Stickland reaction.

p.s: Description of Clostridium litorale sp. nov.
Clostridium litorale (li.to.ra'le. L. adj. n. litorale, at the beach or coast, referring to the source of samples, the seashore of northern Germany, from which the species was isolated)

Rod-shaped cells, 1.0 - 1.5 μm x 2.0 x 8.0 μm in size, with rounded ends; motile; ovoid spores (1.5 x 2.0 μm) formed subterminally in old cultures, preferentially on agar medium or in litmus milk; gram-reaction negative, also in young cultures; gram-positive cell wall.
Strictly anaerobic chemoorganotroph , and no carbohydrates are fermented.
Betaine is reductively cleaved as oxidant in the Stickland reaction into trimethylamine and acetate with hydrogen, glycine, L-alanine, L-leucine, L-isoleucine, L-valine or L-phenylalanine.
Sarcosine is fermented with L-alanine as electron donor and utilizes glycine and L-serine.
In complex standard media acetate and butyrate are the major fermentation products.
Hydrogen sulfide is produced and growth is stimulated by Tween 80.
Gas, indole, ammonia or hydrogen are not produced.
It is positive for esculin hydrolysis, reduction of neutral red and resazurin and catalase and oxidase negative.
Lipase, lecithinase or urease is not produced.
Meat and milk are not digested and gelatine and starch not hydrolyzed.
Nitrate, sulfate, thiosulfate or sulfite are not reduced.
No complex nutrients required
Temperature range. 13°C-38.5°C; optimum growth at 28°C.
pH Range. 6.5-8.4; optimum growth at 7.3.
NaCl.
Optimum at 1.0%, growth completely inhibited by 6.0% NaCl.
DNA base ratio: 26.1% G + C (thermal denaturation).
Habitats.
Anoxic marine mesophilic sediments from the North Sea, Germany.
Type strain: Strain W6, DSM 5388, deposited in Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen GmbH, Braunschweig, FRG.
